title: It was a long time ago
content:
Erm… I’ve got another tricky question — does anyone know who where members of the jury for the very first Letraset International Typeface Competition in 1973 ? The winning entries were Bombere by Carla Bombere (where is she now ?), Magnificat by Friedrich Peter (how come this incredible design is NOT available as a software font ?) and Stilla by François Boltana.  
Thank you very much

 [‹ ATYPi conference](http://web.archive.org/web/20081023161718/http:/www.typophile.com/node/20978 "Go to previous forum topic") [Setting up own company ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081023161718/http:/www.typophile.com/node/20949 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Celeste

comments.content:
[http://cgi.ebay.com/rare-1973-Letraset-Catalog-vintage-graphic-design\_W0...](http://web.archive.org/web/20081023161718/http:/cgi.ebay.com/rare-1973-Letraset-Catalog-vintage-graphic-design_W0QQitemZ4633476016QQcategoryZ378QQcmdZViewItem "http://cgi.ebay.com/rare-1973-Letraset-Catalog-vintage-graphic-design\_W0QQitemZ4633476016QQcategoryZ378QQcmdZViewItem")

You might need someone with this catalogue or rather the insert. There has been discussion about Magnificat on Typophile, I can’t track it down at the moment.  
Tim

or this book  
 [http://www.eyemagazine.com/review.php?id=72&rid=404](http://web.archive.org/web/20081023161718/http:/www.eyemagazine.com/review.php?id=72&rid=404 "http://www.eyemagazine.com/review.php?id=72&rid=404")

[http://www.google.com/search?client=safari&rls=en&q=Magnificat+site:typo...](http://web.archive.org/web/20081023161718/http:/www.google.com/search?client=safari&rls=en&q=Magnificat+site:typophile.com&ie=UTF-8&oe=UTF-8 "http://www.google.com/search?client=safari&rls=en&q=Magnificat+site:typophile.com&ie=UTF-8&oe=UTF-8")

nb I think the google search has several links to the same thread and most of them you will have to look at the cache rather than the original thread}

Oh thank you very much, Tim — it happens that I do have this book, but it’s so packed with information that I’m never able to remember what’s exactly in it. Therefore, I rarely use it, which is indeed a shame.

You are welcome, I’ve got to say that is a very obscure/esoteric question can I ask why you want to know?  
Tim
Because I’ve just written an article about the legacy of Letraset and dry-transfert lettering for French graphic design monthly <cite>étapes</cite>.
